audio_caption: The audio features two male speakers introducing themselves. The first speaker identifies himself as Sasha and explains that he coordinated the search and rescue teams during the event, serving as the head of the mission. The second speaker introduces himself as Darius, indicating that he was part of the winch team, mainly as a captain. Then, a female speaker asks them to discuss the history of Yuventa, specifically mentioning when it was born and why.

The audio starts with a male speaker reflecting on something being "more a campaign" than a proper search and rescue effort. He notes the involvement of young people from Berlin in welcoming moments in 2015 in Germany. He says that the goal was "to be recognized" and force the state to take over again and launch another "Mare nostrum" kind of mission. He says that it "was not happening" so "they had the ship" and asked around for people to join the crew. Another male speaker adds that there have been 15 other missions so it was 16 total missions in one year, and then in August 2017 the Iuventa was seized. He explains it was in operation for one year, but that they managed to save over 14,000 lives, and that it is amazing because every person who does not die is "a reason to go out and do this work."  A female voice then says something indiscernible.

The audio clip begins with a conversational exchange between two speakers. One speaker, a female, inquires about the evolution of rescue operations at sea during the Juventus experience. A male speaker responds, stating that while the rescue mission itself hasn't changed much in terms of technique and crew size, the behavior of the European, specifically the Italian state, has evolved in their efforts to suppress these rescue operations. He says they have developed new tools to stop civil sea rescue. He then expresses the horror of people dying at sea, compounded by the frustration of sitting through trials in court. Another male speaker joins in, indicating there are two major changes. A musical element with an unknown genre follows, along with ongoing speech.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the Libyan coast guard, mentioning their presence and activities. He notes their involvement in intervening in rescues, but also their reported kidnapping of people from boats and their forced return to Libya, which he describes as a "major change." The speaker's tone is informative.

The clip features a male speaker discussing laws and regulations affecting ships, particularly concerning chip transfers and port operations. He mentions a specific decree and highlights challenges such as ships being stuck in ports due to administrative reasons.  He references rescues and the port's safety assignments, noting how these regulations can cause delays in transferring people. Furthermore, he explains that failure to adhere to these rules can lead to detentions.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker asking if it's true that a rescue mission was aborted to return to port, and if hidden microphones were placed on the ship. A male voice confirms it, detailing the situation in May 2017. He recalls being engaged in a rescue operation with other NGO ships, being asked to transfer people to a court of safety, which was denied. After negotiations, only a portion of the people were allowed to transfer, and they ended up with five miners. The male speaker mentions being ordered by the MCC Rome to transfer these people to Lampedusa, despite other NGOs present at the scene calling for help. They indicated seeing ten boats on the horizon, feeling overwhelmed and at their limit of capacity. The authority dismissed the urgency saying they'd send help anyway.

The clip begins with one male speaker recalling how they arrived in Lampedusa and soon learned about ship blockades. Then, another male speaker explains that around twenty-one boats were distressed over three days, with five disappearing, implying possible drowning of up to 1000 people. He expresses distress, questioning why they were taken out of the rescue and not allowed to help.

The clip starts with a female speaker inquiring about the role of the "national antimafia directorate" in managing Europe's Southern maritime border. This is followed by a male speaker recommending everyone read an article by "Lorenzo D'Agostino" in "The Intercept."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the anti-mafia prosecution in Italy and its role in cracking down on smuggling networks. He notes that Libyan smuggling networks were identified as a new target, a new kind of mafia. The speaker mentions how they used a technique from the fight against the mafia, "going for the small fishes and then going up the the ladder and finding the the bigger fishes."

The clip starts with a male speaker describing an operation involving ships and police officers conducting interviews immediately after rescue operations, seemingly targeting the most vulnerable moments of rescued individuals. He mentions the goal of identifying and arresting individuals steering the boats or holding compasses, labeling them as part of a "smuggling network," despite knowing these people were themselves on the move and not part of the network. He ends by saying they "needed these moments". Then a male speaker is heard.

The audio clip features a single male speaker. He speaks in a measured tone discussing the interference of civilian fleets with police actions. He mentions that one reason for being targeted was the idea of placing police officers on their ships, which was part of a so-called "code of conduct" or accusing them of "colluding with smugglers" to stop their missions and regain a clear field of operations.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker inquiring about a case against someone, asking about its stage. Following this, a male speaker begins, expressing that certain actions look good for statistics against smugglers, but claims "they are no smugglers themselves." He argues that people are searching for freedom and life and have the right to come to Europe and apply for asylum. He believes everyone should be able to exercise this right without risking their lives. He mentions that they are charged with "aiding and abetting illegal immigration." The male speaker then states that 21 people are charged in a "really, really big trial" because of "helping people to immigrate illegal to Italy" and adds that it's not illegal to come to Europe and ask for asylum.
